origin.title: My Origin
body: My engineering journey began with curiosity and precision. As a child in Egypt, I dreamed of becoming an astronaut or pilot. When poor eyesight made that path impossible, my fascination shifted to the machines themselves—aircraft, rockets, and automated systems that operate with extreme accuracy and minimal human intervention.

I studied engineering in Egypt, but early on I realized that technical knowledge alone was not enough. I wanted to build things, not just understand them. This led me to the Information Technology Institute (ITI) in Giza, where I specialized in applied mechatronics. Shortly after, I made one of the most defining decisions of my life: moving alone to Germany to pursue my master’s degree.

That transition was far from smooth. The language barrier was severe, financial conditions changed unexpectedly, and I found myself navigating a new country with limited resources and no support network. Those years shaped me profoundly. I learned discipline, self-reliance, and how to stay functional and focused under sustained pressure.

Alongside my studies, I pursued hands-on experience through industry projects, moving from software testing into development and control-related work. Sports—especially handball—played a crucial role in my integration, reinforcing teamwork, accountability, and leadership in environments where performance mattered more than background.

I entered the automotive industry during the global financial crisis, a period that tested both resilience and adaptability. This journey culminated in joining WABCO (ZF), where I stepped into ADAS development—work that aligned precisely with the original motivation that led me to engineering: building intelligent, safety-critical systems with real impact.

Today, I bring the perspective of someone who has built a career across cultures, languages, and uncertainty. I lead through credibility rather than title, continuously learning—whether the challenge is technical, organizational, or human.

mindset.title: The Growth Mindset: Calculated Risky Adventure
body: You can read books about the Growth Mindset and believe in the theory, but you cannot advocate for it until you have been tested. To me, it isn't a soft skill; it is a calculated risk adventure. I allow myself and the people around me to make mistakes—but only once. A mistake is a data point; a repetition is a system failure.
Curiosity as a Competitive Advantage

If I have one talent, it is curiosity. I leverage it to make difficult decisions that others avoid. Every high-stakes pivot in my life was rewarded handsomely, though often preceded by significant 'work and suffering.' That is the price of the adventure.
• The Pivot: Leaving a secure job for a post-grad degree.
• The Reset: Moving to Germany with zero language skills.
• The Crisis: Starting my career in 2008 at a below-average wage to enter the right field.
• The Gamble: Sinking every dime into real estate to learn the mechanics.
• The Failure: Starting a drop-shipping company that failed but taught me 'Business 101.'
• The Grind: Taking the CFA in my 40s while balancing fatherhood and an ADAS career.
I am curious. I learn. I fail. I learn even more. Then, and only then, I grow. Growth is a system that keeps getting examined.

career.title: Automotive, Embedded SW, AI & Robotics
body: Since childhood, my answer to 'what do you want to be when you grow up?' was unconventional: 'I want to be a God.' This wasn't about ego; it was a fascination with autonomous intelligent systems. The moment I brought my first microcontroller to life in undergrad, my mission was set: building intelligent systems that protect people and the planet. Today, I lead R&D for commercial vehicle ADAS—designing 'big toys for big boys' that save lives.

Since 2009, I have evolved a core philosophy: I don't just lead teams; I build robust development architectures. My approach is rooted in the 'V-Model' of both software and people, ensuring that scalability is baked into the process from day one.
• 30% Faster pre-dev cycles via rapid prototyping.
• ASPICE Mastery: Closing gaps with lean, systematic solutions.
• Automation First: Scripting away failures (like broken dashboards).
• 40% Reduction in problem reports via high-integrity handling.
• Human Scaling: Strengthening strengths via proactive coaching.
• Global Reach: Coordinating hundreds of FTEs for Tier-1 OEMs.

I believe a leader must remain functional in the field. I maintain my technical edge—taking on dev tasks and deep-dive reviews—to ensure I never ask for an output I don't fundamentally understand. I act as the high-bandwidth bridge between strategic vision and the tactical reality of the engineering floor.

fitness.title: My Fitness Journey
body: My mother always described me as 'restless.' I had a biological need to move—ALWAYS. I started sports at age six and haven't stopped since. After five years of Karate and reaching a brown belt, I hit a bureaucratic wall: a three-year wait for the black belt. Being too restless to wait, I pivoted to Handball at age 11, and that is where my real training began.

I’ll be honest: I was the 'talentless' player. I was fit enough to make the team but made enough mistakes to be the target of frustration. I spent five years training relentlessly—gym sessions, basketball, tennis, volleyball, even Judo and Kung Fu—all to find the missing edge. One day, the work paid off. I became a key high-scorer for the U18s and was scouted for the First Team. It taught me that consistency eventually overcomes a lack of initial calibration.
<div class='p-3 bg-light border-start border-4 border-primary mb-4'>

After moving to Germany, I decided to codify this experience. I became a Certified Fitness & Nutrition Coach specializing in Functional Training. Today, I apply the same 'high-performance' logic to individuals and teams that I apply to my engineering projects.
'Sports reinforced teamwork, accountability, and leadership in environments where performance mattered more than background.'

investment.title: Me, My Finance & I
body: I grew up in a classic Egyptian middle-class household. My father, a chemical engineer, taught me that security comes from a well-paying job and disciplined saving. To this day, I have a visceral hatred for 'waste'—whether it is inefficient code or unnecessary luxury. For years, the term 'budget' felt in-born, but I realized that saving alone doesn't scale wealth; it only preserves it.

To understand the 'Difference between rich and middle-class,' I did what any engineer would do: I reverse-engineered the system. I didn't just read books; I took an unpaid internship at a Real Estate firm, renovated homes with my own hands to understand the 'hardware' of property, and eventually acquired multiple investment objects in Germany.
<div class='p-3 bg-light border-start border-4 border-warning mb-4'>

I codified this knowledge by challenging the CFA Level 1 exam—and passing on the first attempt. This isn't just a certificate; it's a commitment to professional-grade analytical rigor. I now view every engineering R&D roadmap through the 'Investment Triangle': Risk, Return, and Time-to-Value.
'In the Lab, money is not for spending; it is a resource to be allocated for maximum system growth.'
